This is a good and informative video, but I think something needs to be added. While vets often do look for hyperarousal states, or for life or death thrill seeking, this is because of their trauma.

Part of our vets who experience war firsthand, is still overseas. They never got to integrate that part of themselves into their civilian identity. It's like they are two people, one the soldier whos seen all this death and destruction, and the other is a civillian father, a mother, a husband, and/or brother.

The main reason why there's this dissonance is because their pain is "unspeakable", or it's expected of them to suffer in silence. When what they really need is to share their pain, and stories, even (sometimes especially) at inappropriaye times.

I have P.T.S.D., and it can make you feel like a hollow person. Like, everyone else is having fun and enjoying life, and you think you're happy too; but there's this gnawing hollow feeling inside that just dulls the happiness and emotions. Then there's the flashbacks, and how inane inocuous things can suddenly become a threat against your life!

Vets need to be able to talk about these things candidly at any time, because they will happen at any time. They need to be addressed on the spot. This is the only way the soldier and civillian can become one person again.

So, the addiction to the high stress situation, is also a way for the survivor of a life or death situation to "feel alive again"; Because a part of them is trapped in the past trauma, and that part is screaming for attention!

A long time ago wars happened because resources were scarce. Resources are still scarce, but we've found various mechanisms of making the most out of it.
Despite everything, the 21st century remains one of the most peaceful era's in human history. You may equally well find that encouraging or depressing.


In the modern day, society has become sufficiently self aware that it doesn't like war and thus exerts significant efforts trying to resolve disputes diplomatically.

It has been enormously successful in this as was noted above, such that more abstract concerns such as population, resource management, and environmental destruction have began encroaching on collective tendency to worry.

Nevertheless, there is always a desperate concern at the back of our minds that the awful awfuls may happen and war will become inevitable.



As a result, we maintain armies.


From there all our troubles begin.


The problem with maintaining an army is that it requires experienced veterans to be around in order to train the greenhorns. But the only way to have experiences soldiers is to send them off to fight a war and the only way to fight a war is either to start one or have someone else declare war.

Nobody is particularly interested in getting flattened by the US army, so despite maintaining one of the largest military forces in the world and being in the greatest need of experienced military personnel, war that they can enter into conscience free as the result of a belligerent foreign entity getting it's nark on are virtually non-existent.



So we find ourselves in the baffling situation of developed nations carefully pulling the strings behind the scenes in order to arrange practice wars just on the off chance that a real war is just around the corner.



Only these are real wars.

It may be our practice, but it their country that is being deceived and torn to shreds.

They've just been carefully manipulated so that developed nations like the US doesn't have to accept responsibility for initiating them. Otherwise nobody would agree to fight and the government would have war of a completely different and domestic character waged on it.



The only person that can be seriously credited as insane enough to challenge Godzilla the US would be a religious extremist who is not overly concerned whether he lives or dies anyway as long as it's in the name of the cause and he gets to have paradise in the afterlife. Thus the middle east is ripe for being coaxed into becoming the perfect punching bag.



For this reason it is safe to assume that this recent war in Iran is just same old misanthropic charade and has already been vetted to make sure it is in no way liable to start WW3. I know, I know -- how disappointing.



Sure there's terrorist attacks to worry about a well -- but surely this is a small price to pay for strong, well-trained soldiers who can keep us safe in the event of war?


There's the nuclear option too, but that's even more self-refuting: a weapon so powerful it can never ever be used because the world itself would fall apart.

The main trend of anthropological and scholarly thinking says the opposite of what you say about primitive societies. The main scientific view - and there are differences of expert opinion, since the evidence is scant for preliterate societies - is that the earlier societies were more violent than the later ones: hunter-gatherer more violent than agricultural societies, agricultural societies more violent than industrial. Even though the average war has become more destructive as society grows more efficient, there are so many fewer wars that the overall death rate from war and murder goes down with societal progress.
There are of course blips, it is not constant progress. The biggest exceptions come from societies that regress into ideologically militant regimes. This brings back frequent war. The most devastating cases have been the socialist and totalitarian regimes, which have been consistently the most militarist, as we have seen with every independent Communist state, measured both by their wars and their military spending, and saw earlier with the fascist states. Regimes and movements that use religion as a political ideology have also brought regression to chronic warfare, as we see today with Islamism.
Please try in the future to be statistically accurate in your comparative statements. Social science does exist, and it does not support your biases.

that's interesting. in the beginning you were talking about how we were different when we were hunter gatherers, and we had less to fight about.. that's true because more things were shared possessions, and in addition to that everyone knew each other, too. I have often looked at this progression from the difference of living in a small village (< 2000 population) where everyone pretty much knows each other, to the anonymity provided by living in a small city. the difference is a function of the speed which things get communicated, and because of technology (even such as twitter), communication is increasing at a much more rapid rate, so even though technology like twitter is exacerbating the problem, it's also quelling its effects bit as well.


I think what is happening with the rumours of war is that it's actually being used to keep us in a more of a survival mental state, because if in actuality a real war did begin, twitter would be the best thing for disseminating the news that doesn't want to be broadcasted.


twitter makes fighting a war and keeping the information that's not meant to be public much more difficult, yet enables rumours of war quite a bit -- just like rumours in a small village :) welcome to the beginnings of the new global village...

Although ACTH has the ability to release adrenaline from adrenal glands it's important to notice that main release mechanism is direct stimulation by sympathetic nervous system fibers. This is important because hormonal pathway takes much more time and time is crucial in fight or flight.
Our phones and the mass media hijack our brain With whatever they decide to put on the news that day

ACTH is Adreno-cortico-trophic-hormone
Meaning it increases the hormonal secretions from the suprarenal CORTEX, while Adrenaline and noradrenaline are secreted from the suprarenal MEDULLA.

ACTH doesn't stimulate adrenaline and noradrenaline secretion!!!

Maybe you meant "sympathetic discharge from the Central Nervous System", caused by the "stressors". This DOES increase the adrenaline and noradrenaline in the blood.

ACTH increases Cortisol secretion, which in turn increases the sympathetic discharge as well...

the idea that people were less aggressive/prone to violence in hunter-gatherer societies is a common urban myth that has been thoroughly debunked for centuries by now. This whole idea was invented by the philosophers of the enlightenment as a jab at monarchies (especially in the confessions of Rousseau, and his theory on the uprooting/denaturation of Man, but also in Diderot's encyclopedia).
What we found in practice was that the overwhelming majority of hunter gatherer tribes we discovered in both Africa and Australia were massively more violent than the average sedentary community in the rest of the world (In Australia especially, war/raids were the single most common cause of death amongst aborigines people when they were first discovered.
Honestly I blame Yuval Noah Harari and his book "Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind" for re-popularizing this myth.
Now I finally understand why Dr Watson misses war so much lol

We were not less violent as hunter gatherers. To see a different perspective read The Better Angels of Our Nature by Steven Pinker, or papers by Azar Gat and Richard Wrangham. Rates of murder are higher in non-state societies

Great video!! The part about soldiers missing combat or war reminded me of an interesting TED Talk about Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs.
The guy giving the talk proposed that one of the reasons the soldiers miss the military life style is because it fills the "Belonging" Tier better than anything in civilian life. With a normal army platoon being around 50 soldiers and with each individual willing to sacrifice anything to help someone else in the group. This is very similar to how early hunter-gatherer societies were structured, thus filling the psychological need more like what it evolved in to begin with.
Just an interesting point to ponder. Keep up the good work!!!😁

Okay, I’m going to go on a bit of a tangent that involves some medical conditions of mine.

Now, you said that the pituitary gland is involved in the fight-or-flight response, correct? According to my medical card (which is the only thing with my medical diagnosis on it), the first word in my diagnosis is “Panhypopituitarism”. What I know is that my pituitary gland is smaller than it should be. So, my body can’t produce as much hormone (or no hormone) compared to a normal person. Would this affect the fight or flight response? As in, if I was truly in danger, would the f/f response kick in and give me the strength I need to not die?
